runs.text: Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this fictional, or made-up, story is about a girl who collects and paints rocks.
Have students look at the illustrations to identify the main character.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means to plan on doing something.
to do their homework after they have a snack.
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the phrase in the first paragraph that describes Renata. (rock collector)
What does Renata intend to do with the rocks after she paints them? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Which word describes Renata: selfish or giving? Explain.
What can you do to make someone smile today?
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this comic is about soil and people who work with soil. The narrator is Gregor, a gopher, and his words are in speech bubbles.
Tell students to pay careful attention to the details in the photos.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
is something made of smaller parts that are now mixed together.
of yogurt and berries into the bowls.
A jar of coins can have a
of quarters, dimes, nickels, and pennies.
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word in the title that has an -
What is dirt a mixture of? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why do Doctor Lee and Farmer Johnson work together? Explain.
Do you think soil is gross or interesting? Why?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students circle words that end with
. Have them draw boxes around words that end with
. Then have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss phrasing, or how to chunk longer sentences into meaningful parts.
For example, as you read sentence 5, pause briefly after visitors and notice.
Point out that each group of words provides more detail about the previous group.
Read the title. Explain that these are riddles.
Each riddle contains clues about a noun. Students must identify the word.
For the first reading, read the first riddle and have students read the other riddles. Invite volunteers to solve each riddle.
Then have students reread the riddles in pairs, alternating lines. Partners can switch lines during the rereadings.
Prompt students to find all of the words with suffixes
and circle them.  Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board, and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that students will read a procedural text about how to make a terrarium, which is a small habitat for plants and/or animals.
Have students look at the materials list and diagram to identify what a terrarium contains.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
How do you know if a plant has received a
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word in the first sentence that has a suffix. (gardener)
How can you tell that the terrarium has a sufficient amount of soil? Find the sentence that answers this question.
How does the diagram help you understand the directions? Explain.
Would you like to make your own terrarium?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students circle words with suffixes
. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
Have them read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss the different end punctuation for sentences 1 (exclamation point), 2 (period), and 4 (question mark).
Model how you change your intonation when reading a question (raise voice at end) or exclamation (read with emotion).
Then have students read the sentences consecutively.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this text is about preparing for a beach day and includes a list.
Have students read the heading above the list to identify its purpose.
Guide students through a reading of the text, including the list.
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the list.

Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the e-book for support before they read the book on their own.
Explain to students that they will read a story about a girl going to the beach with her sister and grandma.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
after the new library was built.
Have you ever seen a building get
Have students whisper read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names the grandmothers job. (teacher)
What demolished the sandcastle? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How are the narrator and the narrators sister alike? How are they different?
Would you rebuild the sandcastle after it was destroyed? Why or why not?
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat.
Explain that this text is an interview about a recent mudslide. In the interview, a reporter asks questions and two people answer them.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
reason for becoming a veterinarian is her love of animals.
What do you think is the
way we can protect, or keep safe, Earths environment?
Have students whisperread the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that tells who is asking the questions in this text. (reporter)
According to Will, what is the primary cause of the mudslide? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why does the reporter interview James and Will about the mudslide? Explain.
What are some ways that people can help others who are affected by natural disasters?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
